p: The above grouping of viruses is likely to be porous and is expected to change with the addition of data from new studies. The interesting question remains, nevertheless, whether Anopheles are less efficient arbovirus vectors than Aedes and Culex, or are simply under-recognized as virus vectors. If the first case were true, that is, lower vector competence of Anopheles for arboviruses, then understanding the biological mechanisms leading to their general resistance to virus transmission would be important and could lead to novel tools to control arbovirus transmission by Aedes and Culex vectors. As the current systematic review indicates, Anopheles are not inherently resistant to virus replication. Although the natural virome data do not yet exist to make a numerical comparison with Aedes and Culex, there is no evidence that rates of natural carriage of viruses are substantially different between these mosquito genera.
